natural problem: When the polynomial $x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^ 2 - 25x + 10$ is divided by $x^2 - 2x + k,$ the remainder is $x + a.$  Enter the ordered pair $(k,a).$
natural solution: The long division is shown below. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -4x & +(8 - k) & \\ \cline{2-6} x^2 - 2x + k & x^4 & -6x^3 & +16x^2 & -25x & +10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -2x^3 & + kx^2 \\

\cline{4-6} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 0 & +(2k - 9)x  & +(k^2 - 8k + 10) \\ \end{array} \]Thus, the remainder is $(2k - 9)x + (k^2 - 8k + 10).$  We want this to be $x + a,$ so $2k - 9 = 1$ and $k^2 - 8k + 10 = a.$  Solving, we find $(k,a) = \boxed{(5,-5)}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + a"
and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (P x div Q x) + R x"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the polynomial $x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^ 2 - 25x + 10$ is divided by $x^2 - 2x + k,$ the remainder is $x + a.$  Enter the ordered pair $(k,a).$ The final Answer is (5,-5)
 ### Proof
 The long division is shown below. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -4x & +(8 - k) & \\ \cline{2-6} x^2 - 2x + k & x^4 & -6x^3 & +16x^2 & -25x & +10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -2x^3 & + kx^2 \\ 
 \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -4x^3 & +(16 - k)x^2   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &- 4x^3 & +8x^2 & - 4kx \\  \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(4k - 25)x   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(2k - 16)x & +k(8 - k) \\
 \cline{4-6} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 0 & +(2k - 9)x  & +(k^2 - 8k + 10) \\ \end{array} \]Thus, the remainder is $(2k - 9)x + (k^2 - 8k + 10).$  We want this to be $x + a,$ so $2k - 9 = 1$ and $k^2 - 8k + 10 = a.$  Solving, we find $(k,a) = \boxed{(5,-5)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + a"
and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (P x div Q x) + R x"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given the functions P, Q, R such that P(x) = x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^2 - 25x + 10, Q(x) = x^2 - 2x + k, and R(x) = x + a. If P(x) divides Q(x) and for all x, P(x) equals to Q(x) times the quotient of P(x) divided by Q(x) plus R(x), find the values of k and a. The final answer is (k, a) = (5, -5).

a_1.formal problem:

and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"

shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + a"
and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * x + R x"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given three real functions $P(x) = x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^2 - 25x + 10$, $Q(x) = x^2 - 2x + k$, and $R(x) = x + a$. It is known that $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)$ and $P(x) = Q(x) * x + R(x)$. Find the values of $k$ and $a$. The final answer is $(k, a) = (5, -5)$.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (x + a)"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose we have two polynomial functions, $P(x) = x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^2 - 25x + 10$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 2x + k$. Also, we know that $P(x)$ is a divisor of $Q(x)$, and $P(x)$ can be expressed as the product of $Q(x)$ and $(x + a)$. Find the values of $k$ and $a$. The final answer is $k = 5$ and $a = -5$.

 ### Proof
 The long division is shown below. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -4x & +(8 - k) & \\ \cline{2-6} x^2 - 2x + k & x^4 & -6x^3 & +16x^2 & -25x & +10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -2x^3 & + kx^2 \\ 
 \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -4x^3 & +(16 - k)x^2   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &- 4x^3 & +8x^2 & - 4kx \\  \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(4k - 25)x   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(2k - 16)x & +k(8 - k) \\
 \cline{4-6} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 0 & +(2k - 9)x  & +(k^2 - 8k + 10) \\ \end{array} \]Thus, the remainder is $(2k - 9)x + (k^2 - 8k + 10).$  We want this to be $x + a,$ so $2k - 9 = 1$ and $k^2 - 8k + 10 = a.$  Solving, we find $(k,a) = \boxed{(5,-5)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and k a :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + (x + a)"
shows  "k = 5" and "a = -5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given the functions $P(x) = x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^2 - 25x + 10$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 2x + k$ and $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)$. Also given that $P(x) = Q(x)R(x) + (x + a)$ for all $x$. Find the values of constants $k$ and $a$. The final answer is $k = 5$ and $a = -5$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a k :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + a"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the polynomial $x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^ 2 - 25x + 10$ is divided by $x^2 - 2x + k,$ the remainder is $x + a.$  Enter the ordered pair $(k,a).$ The final Answer is (5,-5)
 ### Proof
 The long division is shown below. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -4x & +(8 - k) & \\ \cline{2-6} x^2 - 2x + k & x^4 & -6x^3 & +16x^2 & -25x & +10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & -2x^3 & + kx^2 \\ 
 \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -4x^3 & +(16 - k)x^2   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &- 4x^3 & +8x^2 & - 4kx \\  \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(4k - 25)x   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & +(8 - k)x^2 & +(2k - 16)x & +k(8 - k) \\
 \cline{4-6} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 0 & +(2k - 9)x  & +(k^2 - 8k + 10) \\ \end{array} \]Thus, the remainder is $(2k - 9)x + (k^2 - 8k + 10).$  We want this to be $x + a,$ so $2k - 9 = 1$ and $k^2 - 8k + 10 = a.$  Solving, we find $(k,a) = \boxed{(5,-5)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a k :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 6 * x powr 3 + 16 * x powr 2 - 25 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 2 * x + k"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + a"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "(k, a) = (5, -5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given three functions $P(x) = x^4 - 6x^3 + 16x^2 - 25x + 10$, $Q(x) = x^2 - 2x + k$, and $R(x) = x + a$. If the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $Q(x)$ is equal to $R(x)$ for all $x$, find the values of $k$ and $a$. The final answer is $k=5$ and $a=-5$.
